ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a solid knowledge of the foundations of Classical Arabic.
I learned how to translate much Quranic Arabic and it proves very useful when I read the Quran.
Grammar, punctuation, and verbs for formal Arabic

I began to learn the grammar of Classical Arabic; we covered the first half of Thackston's textbook, concentrating on the inflection of Form 1 verbs. I also gained exposure to Arabic literature through class discussions and a trip to the Beinecke.
Classical Arabic grammar and syntax. By the end of the semester, you'll be reading a few surahs from the Qur'an.

I learned how to conjugate sound verbs and irregular verbs, read Classical Arabic text, and a multitude of different grammar rules. I am now able to read the Quran with a little bit more understanding, as I am now more aware of the grammar rules and such.
I learned more Arabic grammar and developed translational skills when it comes to classical texts. This class helped me interpret the Quran better and understand commonly used Islamic phrases.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I thought the course was very strong overall, and I can't think of any ways in which it should be improved.
Although the class was taught great, I do wish it was a bit more structured. This could be improved by relying less on the book and more on practice.
A major weakness was the heavy reliance on the textbook
Lots of involvement from the students however the book was difficult to understand so I hope that thered be a more concise book

The course had a strong emphasis on grammar, but we also practiced reading aloud. Sometimes we looked a hadith or a modified sura in addition. I appreciated the time we took on the grammatical elements of the language. I can't really think of any way to improve the course, though Thackston can be a bit dense.
Miguel is an amazing instructor. He is both incredibly knowledgeable and very patient. I appreciated how available he made himself for office hours. Learned a lot in a very supportive environment.

My strengths included participating in class, asking questions when I did not understand something, and picking up on the grammar rules and conjugation patterns. My weaknesses included not being able to memorize vocal efficiently enough and store it in my long-term memory as well as struggling to read and understand the textbook for the class.

The information and grammar we learned was very useful and I found it very interesting. The book, however, was extremely difficult to learn from. In the future, this course should use a different book.

I liked the pacing of the class towards the end and appreciated that the instructor's focus was on the students' improvement and not on a letter grade. However, I wish there was more transparency in regards to grading and that the class didn't hinge on the fact that students were already exposed to certain grammatical terms. Most of us taking this course had never taken a formal grammar class and a lot of the terms were brand new, but it was expected of us to already know and memorize it which hindered our learning later on.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely
Yes, I do recommend this course. However, make sure you are actively studying because there is a lot of material to be taught.
If your interested in classical language study yes. It was quite challenging though because the course relied on a textbook that was difficult to understand for non-linguistics/classics major.

Yes I would. Professor Monteiro taught the class effectively and was always available to help. If youre not a native Arabic speaker, this class would be the one to take to improve writing and reading.

I would recommend this class to anyone who wants to read texts in Classical Arabic, or is interested in the nuances of Arabic grammar! It felt like a very strong introduction and I look forward to continuing work in the spring.

Arabic is a beautiful language, so if you want to really understand its grammar, then you'll want to take this class. Take it with Miguel if you can--he always gave great insights that went beyond the textbook we used.

I would recommend this class to a student who already has previous knowledge of old language and has experience reading complicated textbooks that were not written for someone just beginning Classical Arabic. As I was not one of these students, I struggled a lot with grasping the main, important concepts for some time.
Yes if you would like to learn how to read classical texts like the Quran with a better intuition of how to translate and understand the text.

I would recommend this class if you have a lot of time in your schedule to study the material outside of class. A lot of the content you really need to put time and effort into outside of class to fully grasp it.
